Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Tardis materialises amidst the dunes by a golden beach, played by Climping beach, Littlehampton, West Sussex.

Dialogue.Line: Where are we, Doctor?
We're by the seaside, that's where we are. That's all that matters.
Aye, but where?
Yes, Doctor, we must know.
Oh, stop fussing, you two. Come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor runs down the slope to the beach.

Dialogue.Line: Come on, you two. No, wait a minute. See if there's any buckets and spades in the Tardis.
Buckets and spades? Is he going to dig for worms?
No, he wants us to play sand castles.
Sand castles? What does he think we are, a couple of children?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor runs along the sand, then notices a hovercraft moored further along the shore and waves at it.
The man is Australian.

Dialogue.Line: Hey, Rod, pass me those binoculars.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Rod opens the hatch of the hovercraft.

Dialogue.Line: Now what's biting you?
Some crazy nut dancing a jig.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He looks through the binoculars. A third man with curly hair stands up in the hovercraft.

Dialogue.Line: Hey, wait a minute. It can't be. Get below fast, both of you.
What's the matter?
Move!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is down to his long-johns in the surf.

Dialogue.Line: Come on in, the water's lovely. You don't know what you're missing.
Doctor! You'll catch your death.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor plays in the water, and Jamie laughs.

Dialogue.Line: Well, what do you know? You're right, it is him.
What are we going to do?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Anton picks up a handset and sets the dial.

Dialogue.Line: (blonde woman) Yes?
This is Anton.
Where are you?
Ten miles west of Cape Arid. Now listen.
Wait a minute.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: She calls up a map of the area on the wall screen.

Dialogue.Line: What are you doing there?
What do you think we're doing, fishing?
I shouldn't be surprised.
Oh yeah? Well this time we caught a whale. He's here!
Well, that's physically impossible.
It's him all right. There's no shadow of doubt about it.
Oh no, you're making a mistake, you must be.
Now listen, there are three of us here. We've all had a look.
Well, if you're that definite, I'll contact Giles.
No! We'll take care of this ourselves.
Listen, Anton, you'll do nothing without Giles' agreement.
There isn't time!
Make time.
If you think I'm going to pass up a chance like this, you're crazy.
Well, at least wait till I get there.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Transmission ends.

Dialogue.Line: Anton! Anton!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: But Anton is handing out guns.

Dialogue.Line: Giles, that's just what I said. How could it be him? KENT [on monitor]: It's a mistake, it must be.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Played by the BBC's resident Australian, Bill Kerr.

Dialogue.Line: Yes, I know, but he was definite. He's going to kill him. KENT [on monitor]: I don't care. Get after them, stop them!
But Giles, what can I do? KENT [on monitor]: Look, I don't care what you do, Astrid, but stop them!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor has got dressed again.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, there's nothing like a dip to freshen you up.
Hey, there's a funny looking boat.
That's not a boat, it's a hovercraft.
Eh?
It's a hovercraft. It floats on the air instead of the sea.
Oh, yes? Yeah, I'm too old for fairy tales.
No, it's true, Jamie.
What a terrifying thing. It's like a sea monster.
Oh, we'll soon get a closer look. It's coming nearer.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The hovercraft is coming straight for them.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, yes. Yes. I don't think I like the look of this. Let's go.
Why? What's the matter?
Come on, run.
But Doctor
Don't argue, run. Come on.
What do you mean, run?
Come on!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Curly and Anton shoot at the travellers as they run for the sand dunes.
The Doctor, Jamie and Victoria hide in the grassy dunes.

Dialogue.Line: If only we had a gun.
But why do they want to harm us?
Why indeed? Well, what now?
Look, Doctor, can't we go back to the Tardis?
No, we'd never make it. There's not much cover here.
Perhaps we've landed in a world of mad men.
They're human beings, if that's what you mean, indulging their favourite past time. Trying to destroy each other.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The hovercraft stops at the base of the dunes, and the men disembark with their guns.

Dialogue.Line: Time we went. Come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The travellers sneak amongst the dunes. Anton sends Curly off to the right whilst he and Rod go left. The travellers meet up with Curly. Jamie knocks him out.

Dialogue.Line: Creag an tuire!
Oh, well done.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Anton and Rod see a helicopter coming in to land.

Dialogue.Line: What's that?
I know those markings, that's Astrid's runabout. What's she doing here?
Interfering. We've got to get to him before she does.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor, Jamie and Victoria run again. The helicopter lands. Astrid is flying it.

Dialogue.Line: What is it, Doctor?
Oh, I'm frightened!
Over here! Run!
I can't! I can't!
You must. It's our only chance.
Hurry!
Come on!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The three get aboard as Anton and Rod come Funning. Rod stops to check on Curly.

Dialogue.Line: Leave him.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The helicopter takes off in a hail of bullets.

Dialogue.Line: A very timely and welcome rescue.
Don't speak to me for a moment, please.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor looks at the permit posted in the back of the helicopter - Australasion (sic) Zone. Type Helicopter, (private). Valid until 31st Dec 2018. Class Reg No L23X. Victoria has her arms around Jamie's neck.

Dialogue.Line: But what is this thing, Doctor?
It's a helicopter, Jamie.
Huh?
A chopper. You know, a whirly bird.
He say's it's a bird.
No, no, no. It's a primitive form of flying machine.
Well, at least we're safe now, aren't we?
Depends on what you mean by been safe. They've shot a hole in the fuel tank. We might blow up any minute.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Rod gets Curly back to the hovercraft, then they head back onto the water and follow the helicopter as far as they can. Astrid flies inland to a lone bungalow.

Dialogue.Line: Here we go.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: She lands the helicopter. They all get out, Astrid last of all, holding her left arm.

Dialogue.Line: Wait. You're hurt.
It's nothing. We're lucky to be still alive.
Jamie, give her a hand.
Come along inside.
I'm all right.
Now let's have a look at it. You're not, and please don't argue. Victoria? Bring some warm water will you?
Well, where's the kitchen?
Through the arch. There's a medical kit in the bathroom, through there.
Go and fetch it, will you, Jamie?
Right.
Come and sit down.
It's nothing. It's just a scratch.
We'll see. Oh, yes.
Who are you?
You mean you don't know?
No, why should I?
Well you went to such a great deal of trouble to save us. Ah, there we are. Thank you, Jamie.
Do you know how to use those things?
Oh, don't worry, the Doctor will fix you up just fine.
Jamie!
Oh, you're a doctor?
Well, not of any medical significance.
Doctor of law? Philosophy?
Which law? Whose philosophies, eh?
Oh, I see. You're determined to be mysterious.
Am I?
Doctor of science?
Septic spray. That should be right.
A Doctor of Divinity, then?
You'll run out of doctors in a minute. Now, you haven't told us your name yet.
Astrid Ferrier.
Ah, Miss Ferrier, this is Victoria and this is Jamie.
Hello.
Now, this won't take a minute. I just want to clean it off. Be as gentle as I can. There we are. Who are these men? Why are they so determined to kill us?
Kill you. They hate you.
Me? I'm the nicest possible person.
Or at least I should say they hate the person that they think you are, passionately and completely.
Can't we tell them they've made a mistake?
There wouldn't be time.
They seem remarkably dedicated.
They are.
There.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor finishes dressing her wound.

Dialogue.Line: Tell me, Miss Ferrier, do you hate me?
Far from it. To me you're the most wonderful and marvellous man that's ever dropped out of the skies. Will you do something for me?
Anything, anything at all.
It'll probably cost you your life. Oh, but it would be worth it.
Oh, that's, that's comforting, anyway. What is it that you want me to do?
Let me take you to the man I work for, Giles Kent. He'll explain everything you want to know.
I don't think so, Miss Ferrier. No, I'm sorry.
Can we not just listen, Doctor? There's no harm in that.
There's a great deal of harm in it. You don't suppose Miss Ferrier saved our skins for our sakes, do you? Now what is it you want us for?
You resemble very closely a man who's determined to be dictator of the world. A man who will stop at nothing.
A dictator? Like Napoleon?
Who is he?
Salamander.
Salamander?
I know it's surprising. Let me take you to Giles Kent.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The hovercraft arrives outside.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, you're not going to agree?
The back door! Hurry!
It's too late!
In there!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They hide in another room as Rod comes in through the back door. As he comes through the arch to the living room, Astrid grabs him jumps out from behind the settee and throws him against the wall.

Dialogue.Line: Run for it!
Come on!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Shots are fired through the window, killing Rod.

Dialogue.Line: Miss Ferrier, come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Anton and Curly come in through the front.

Dialogue.Line: But I. He was framed against the window. I saw him, he was trying to get out!
No time now. They'll get away!
There they are!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Curly fires through the window.

Dialogue.Line: Wait! If we can get up in the air above them we can finish this. Now let's get to that helicopter!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor, Astrid, Victoria and Jamie hide in a ditch, and watch Anton and Curly run to the helipad.

Dialogue.Line: The helicopter.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: It takes off, leaking fuel.

Dialogue.Line: It'll blow up!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: And so it does.

Dialogue.Line: I was under the impression you were in the Central European Zone, Leader.
(mexican) That's what you were meant to believe.
Why?
I do not care to be questioned by my own security.
But that's just it. How can I possibly maintain security when you behave like this? I'm at least entitled to know your movements.
You have a policeman's mind, Bruce.
That may be, but only a few days ago you questioned me about this man and his activities, and we agreed that he was dangerous. Now I find you in his office.
Sometimes I like to deal with matters in my own way.
They're not holding you here?
Holding me?
Under some threat or other?
No one threatens Salamander.
I still think I deserve an explanation, Leader.
Yes, of course. You shall have it. But not now. When I return from the Central European Zone.
Very well. Now, what about the dead man found in your bungalow. He was one of your lot, wasn't he?
Yes. Er, he was trying to protect me. The other two wanted to kill me.
Now why should they want to do that to a nice young girl like you?
Well I
Obviously they thought I was there.
You?
Yes, Bruce. Just like you a lot of people don't like me.
Don't get clever with me, Kent. I've a good mind to
I am prepared to accept his story.
Well, I'm not.
That's interesting, but not important. I accept it, that's all that matters.
It's beginning to look as if these people are working for you now. Is that right?
You still dare to question me? They have information. I shall get it. I will see you on my return. Now leave me.
McCrimmon, you said?
Aye.
Well, you just watch your step, that's all.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Bruce and his guard leave.

Dialogue.Line: I never said a word.
(normal) Must be the way you look, Jamie.
You were splendid, Doctor.
Thank you.
That was a dangerous game to play.
It paid off. All right, are you with us?
I don't know where you stand, Mister Kent, but you and this Salamander are obviously on opposite sides. That at least is clear. But which side is good? Which side is bad? And why should I interfere?
Well, you're the only man who can help save the world.
But isn't that what Salamander's trying to do?
Don't you understand? Salamander
Just a moment. Jamie, you're unusually quiet. What do you think?
Well, to save the world, aye, well, it sounds grand, but. Oh, we couldn't turn our back on a chance like this, Doctor. Well, at least I know you wouldn't.
We don't know anything about these people.
Astrid saved our lives. She was wounded because of it.
Oh, but Jamie, you don't think
Look, she was
Look, we're right about Salamander. It won't take you long to find out for yourselves.
How do you propose we do that?
He'll be well guarded for a start.
We can hardly steal into his study and go through his papers.
That man Bruce said that he was in the Central European Zone.
It's a long way from Australia.
It's only two hours by rocket.
You could leave almost at once.
Well, what then?
I've had a plan for infiltrating into Salamander's inner circle for some time. Well, I could adapt it for your two friends.
I can arrange three travel warrants and visas. Everything you need.
Just three?
Well one for Astrid, one for you and
Victoria.
Of course.
Oh that's very clever of you. How can you do that? I thought you said you had no official position.
We have a contact there.
He must be a very important person.
He is. Denes, Controller of the Zone.
Oh, I see. What about me?
I think we better have a look at Salamander's Research Station at Kanowa.
Yes. Yes, but from a safe distance, of course.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Kanowa Research Station is a cluster of low buildings inside a perimeter fence, played by Dungeness Power Station in Kent. Entry forbidden except with Planetary Pass. A thin faced man enters.

Dialogue.Line: What is all this? I'll just give you a couple of minutes. I have a meeting.
This is important, Benik.
I hope so. Well?
Salamander's left you in control of the Research Station?
Yes.
Did he go on the rocket for the Central European Zone?
Yes.
Did you see him go aboard?
Hasn't been an accident, has there?
Did you see the rocket take off?
Do you mean did I stand there waving my handkerchief? Hardly. I had too much to do.
You're not a very funny man, Benik. Not to me. Now answer me! Did you actually see him leave?
What is all this?
I've just driven straight here from having spoken to Salamander, not two hundred miles away.
That's impossible.
I don't lie, even to someone like you. He was with Giles Kent.
But he hates Kent.
Exactly.
Kent wasn't holding him by force, was he?
No, I thought of that. Salamander was a wee bit odd, I admit. Not quite his usual self, but he was perfectly in control. All he had to do was bat an eyelid and I'd have knocked off everyone in sight.
Oh well, I don't understand it.

Now, Salamander suggested that he was on his way to the Central European Zone. Now you're in radio contact with him. I want you to talk to him, make sure that Kent hasn't got some hold over him that we don't know about.
He instructed me not to bother him until the conference was over.
Well, I'm countermanding that instruction.
I'm telling you, Bruce, he won't answer. Not till the conference is over. It's too important.
How long will it last?
How should I know? They last three hours, usually.
All right, that'll have to do. Let me have a report as soon as you've spoken to him. Is that clear? Is that clear?
Yes.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Bruce leave, slamming the door. Benik picks up a handset.

Dialogue.Line: I want a direct channel link to Leader Salamander, Ariel TLXKZ. Notify me as soon as he is able to accept transmission. That's all.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: In the Central European Zone, Salamander is sitting at a table with two colleagues.

Dialogue.Line: (East European) This is dreadful news, Salamander. I still can't believe it.
Terrible, terrible.
I don't say it will happen. I say it can happen. Your zone is in danger, Denes. Here, here and here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He points at a map on the table.

Dialogue.Line: We've had no trouble for years in those mountains.
You don't imagine I make it up?
No, no, of course not.
Those volcanoes have been dead since the 16th century. Fedorin is right to doubt.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The intercom buzzes.

Dialogue.Line: A volcano is a strange thing, my friend. I tell you the truth. It's like a man in the hot sun, sleeping. Still, lifeless. Then boom! He wakes full of energy! I know volcanoes.
Isn't there a possibility of a miscalculation for a few degrees?
I'm never wrong. Every one of my predictions has been accurate.
Yes. Your record is good. I don't deny that.
You are too kind. Now will you listen to me?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The buzzing continues. An African woman in a white mini-dress enters.

Dialogue.Line: Leader, the communications
I know! I know! I told you I was not to be disturbed.
Yes, Leader.
No, wait! No, wait Fariah, huh? You'd like some refreshment, perhaps?
Thank you.
No, no, not for me.
Oh, you're going so soon?
I must consult my scientific advisors.
You still don't believe me.
I believe you sufficiently to want to have your information checked before I alarm my people unnecessarily.
Your scientists won't help you. They don't know. They are amateurs.
No, Salamander, they are not amateurs. They are very clever men dedicated to their work, but they are men, capable of human error like anybody else.
Do what you wish. Captain!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A guard enters.

Dialogue.Line: Sir!
Controller Denes is leaving.
Yes, sir.
You will soon see that I am right. (to Fedorin) Oh, you will stay, huh? Have a drink. We have a great deal to talk about, you and I. Fariah, see to him.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Salamander follows Denes indoors.
Jamie and Victoria are seated on a park bench. They have suitcases with them.

Dialogue.Line: Are you sure this is the right one?
I'm not sure of anything after that rocket. But Astrid said it was the third bench on the south walk of the large gardens. Well, here it is, I counted.
Here we are.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Astrid arrives.

Dialogue.Line: It's all arranged. Salamander's in residence in the President's Palace.
What's the card?
That'll get you through the front gate. Find the terrace facing west.
Good luck, Jamie.
Yes, keep your wits about you.
Right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie leaves. Astrid uses a communicator behind the bushes.

Dialogue.Line: Hello. Hello? Australasian Zone? How much longer? Look, don't talk to me about sun spots. What? Well, the Central European Zone. Please don't worry about procedure. This is urgent. Connect me!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Beep.

Dialogue.Line: That might be her now. Yes.
Hello, Giles? This is me, Astrid.
Right, let's have it. What's happening?
Everything's gone fine so far.
Speak up. We can't hear you very well.
Oh, it's these spots.
Oh, she's having spot trouble.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor has picked up a second handset.

Dialogue.Line: Oh yes.
Right, how is the plan working so far?
It's gone fine. The rocket arrived right on time in Hungary, and Jamie's got his entrance pass and has started phase one.
Do you think the boy can handle it?
Well I hope so. My goodness, they're a pretty odd lot though, aren't they?
Well, actually, the Doctor's with me right now.
Oh, I am sorry. Oh, I know I'm sure they'll be fine.
What news of Denes? We must keep him posted as to what is happening.
It's all right. We've contacted and we've arranged to meet.
Be careful, he's pretty well known.
Oh, don't worry. I suggested that we meet under a disused jetty by the river.
Disused Yeti?
No, no, no, no. Jetty, jetty. Er, anything else to tell us?
No. If the plan goes through I'll try and contact you again.
Right. Goodbye, good luck.
Good luck, Astrid. Jamie and Victoria will look after you.
Astrid, are you there? Where. She's gone. And I'm not surprised after that last remark.
Well, I'm sorry.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Fedorin pours himself a drink.

Dialogue.Line: Why don't you sit down?
No.
Why not?
I have never sat out here.
Salamander won't mind.
I would never sit down here.
If you don't like him, why do you work for him?
He has a way of persuading people.
Yes, I can imagine that.
Brujo.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Spanish for sorcerer or witch doctor.

Dialogue.Line: What? If only I knew what he wanted to talk to me about. Would you know?
Salamander talks to many people. Some only once.
Well, I shall know soon enough, I suppose. What exactly do you do here?
I serve.
Yes, but you're obviously not an ordinary servant.
No, I'm not.
What, then?
Would you like some more refreshment?
No, I'll get it myself.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Fedorin pours another drink and downs it quickly.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, that's good.
Is it? I'm very glad to hear that.
What?
I am Salamander's food taster.
Does he need one?
There have been many attempts to poison him.
Dangerous job.
Mmm. That's why it's very nice to have help for a change.
You mean? You mean you haven't?
No. I didn't have time. Still taste good? Nothing bitter?
No. I, I don't think so.
You would know by now, I think.
Oh. Oh, you, you had me worried for a moment. But what on Earth made you take a job as a food taster?
She was hungry. Only thing is, now she has all the food she needs, she's lost her appetite. Give me a drink.
You are well protected.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Salamander clicks his fingers and a guard enters, pointing his gun at Fedorin.

Dialogue.Line: Very well protected. Be calm. Sit down. Drink your drink.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie jumps down onto the terrace from a high wall, knocks out the guard and takes his gun.

Dialogue.Line: Thank you for calling the guard. I was wondering what to do about him. Now don't move for that box! Not if you value your life. Now all of you, back over there! That's it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie takes the intercom box.

Dialogue.Line: Not as well protected as you think you are, hey? Now when I say duck.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie throws the intercom over the side of the terrace.

Dialogue.Line: Duck! Get down!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Astrid triggers a detonator and there is an explosion. As Salamander gets to his feet, Jamie puts the gun on the table. Two guards rush in to shoot Jamie.

Dialogue.Line: Wait! What do you do, boys, huh? Read? Sleep? It's a fine thing. Here we have an attempt to destroy me and where are you? It's not so good, boys. It's not so good. I'm watching you. Look after him.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The guards carry their colleague away.

Dialogue.Line: Better still, get rid of him. What's all this about, huh?
I heard two men talking. They said they'd planted a bomb of some kind in your radio telephone. I tried to warn them at the gates, but they wouldn't pay any attention.
So you break in? How you break in?
Ah well, I'm here on holiday with a friend. She's very pretty, so the guard didn't see me slip past him.
Why didn't you call out and warn me? I nearly used the radio telephone several times.
Ah you'd have had me shot, most like.
Why you risk your skin to save me?
Well, without you the Earth hasn't much of a chance, has it?
You like to work for me, huh? You like that?
Oh no, you don't have to do that. I mean, you owe me nothing.
You're quite right, boy.
And I'm on holiday.
You won't find what I pay you disappointing.
Aye, there's my girlfriend too, though.
Oh we might be able to find something for her, hey Fariah?
Yes. Your chef could use an assistant.
See to it. What do you say, huh?
Well, I'll give it a go. But I'll say this though. Your security system's rotten. There'll have to be changes.
What a boy, huh? Fariah, see he gets some proper uniform instead of this skirt. And bring him and his girlfriend to see me.
Come along, then.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie and Fariah leave.

Dialogue.Line: What an extraordinary young man.
I prize loyalty very highly, my friend, and I repay it very generously, like I do the girl Fariah, huh?
Can I... Can I ask you something?
What is it?
What does Brujo mean?
It's a word we use in Mexico for sorcerer. Why?
Nothing, nothing.
You stay for dinner, huh?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Victoria is sitting on the bench, while Astrid sits at the other reading a book.

Dialogue.Line: Here comes Jamie.
Everything's fine.
Oh, good.
Careful, you might have been followed.
Oh don't worry, they think I've saved his life. Hey, he's offered me a job. To you as well.
That's perfect.
Well done, Jamie.
Well it was nothing. Is it all right your end?
Yes. But it was nothing.
Jamie. Jamie!
What?
Does he look like the Doctor?
Aye, it's so uncanny.
Careful.
What's the matter?
What is it?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Astrid leaves. Fariah approaches with the guard captain.

Dialogue.Line: She must have eyes in the back of her head. So, he's offered the both of us a job.
Oh, good.
Who was that?
Who?
The other girl who was sitting there?
Why don't you leave them alone? Do you have to treat everyone as if they're criminals?
He had no right to leave the Presidential Palace.
He had every right. He came to fetch his girlfriend. Salamander ordered it.
I didn't hear Salamander order it.
Very well, go and ask him. No? Perhaps you're wise.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Captain leaves.

Dialogue.Line: He won't follow me. I am Fariah. How do you do?
This is Victoria.
Hello.
Hello. Jamie tells me you're studying the arts of the kitchen.
Aye, she's a great dishwasher.
I like eating, and I'm hungry.
Then let's see if we can't find you something to do. You can work with me if you like.
Thank you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Astrid checks that she's not being watched then goes underneath the structure. Someone crawls towards her and she takes out her gun.

Dialogue.Line: I used to love to do this sort of thing when I was a boy.
I'm sorry. It was the safest place I could think of.
Oh, it's all right. I'm still fit enough.
Thank you for getting me the necessary documents.
Have you been successful?
So far. Salamander's swallowed it.
I thought he would.
The boy's very confident. The girl, not so much.

See the point is that I'm near enough to him to pick out something. This was the first time I met Salamander. I must say that you were right about him, Astrid. We must get rid of him. He must be stopped.
He will be stopped. I'm returning to Giles Kent. Can you wait till we can take action?
Oh, with a bit of luck, yes.
Fedorin. Can you trust him?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: There are footsteps overhead.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, I've been followed. I thought I'd thrown them off.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: She takes out her gun.

Dialogue.Line: No! There is enough violence as it is. Besides, Salamander mustn't get suspicious. You kill his man and he will begin to think.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: More footsteps join the first set.

Dialogue.Line: You understand that strangers are to be picked up. There's been an attempt on Salamander's life. Very well, return to your patrol.
It's all right. Fedorin, would he betray you in some way?
I'm trying to think of some reason why he should.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Guards stand either side of Denes. Jamie is also in a guard's uniform.

Dialogue.Line: Prisoner's escort, halt!
Bruce, you are head of World Security. I hold you personally responsible for this man Denes.
Why? Don't you trust your own security?
Do I have to insist? My name carries some weight in the councils of the world.
Of course it does.
Well, do as I ask.
Very well.
Fedorin, come with me. We must make a report to the World Authority.
They won't believe a word you tell them.
We shall see. Fedorin.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Salamander leaves. Fedorin stops in front of Fedorin, then follows.

Dialogue.Line: I'll do what I can for you, but I don't want any trouble.
Don't worry. I'm looking forward to facing Salamander in public court. I won't run away.
You've done very well so far, Fedorin.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Salamander turns the dial on a wall safe.

Dialogue.Line: It's nothing but a blackmail.
Blackmail? What have I threatened you with? Nothing.
No. But you would if I refused to.

Fedorin, I keep on telling you, this is just a form of comprehensive insurance, huh? It's nothing for you to worry about. Oh, my dear man, I've done nothing but praise you ever since we first met. I said you should be European Controller. I said I would support you.
You found out things about me. Lies that would damage me.
On the contrary, I'm doing you a good turn. I'm actually suppressing facts about you.
Lies, I tell you.
Lies, truth, who knows. But we wouldn't like to put them to the test, would we, huh?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Salamander puts the dossier in the wall safe and closes it, then gives Fedorin a small case.

Dialogue.Line: There.
What's this?
Used in the right way, at the right time, it can dictate your own future, and the future of Alexander Denes.
Poison?
I want you to take a message. McCrimmon. What are you doing dressed like this?
Leader's orders.
Well, as you're here, I've got some questions I want to ask you.
I've better things to do, thank you.
I want to know what Salamander and Giles Kent were discussing when I saw you last.
It's not for me to tell you that.
I'm concerned with Salamander's safety. Giles Kent is supposed to be his bitter enemy.
Look, if Salamander wishes you to know that, I dare say he'll tell you himself. You'll get no confidences out of me.
Well, how much longer am I to be kept here? You choose to be insolent?
We're waiting for the security hovercar. The volcanic eruptions have disrupted everything.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Captain approaches.

Dialogue.Line: You, Captain. Isn't there a room I could wait in?
I'm simply obeying orders.
Perhaps you might interpret your orders differently, huh?
Mister Denes, what can I do? You are no longer the Controller. You're a prisoner here.
Captain? Why is Mister Denes being kept in the corridor here?
It's easier to guard him here.
Are you all right?
Yes, thank you.
Something to read, perhaps?
That would be a comfort, yes.
The Controller is not to be treated as a convicted man before his trial. See he has whatever he wants.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Bruce leaves.

Dialogue.Line: What can I get for you?
Well, if we have to wait, something to eat and drink.
Very well.
Prison rations, Captain?
Certainly not. Nothing but the best for Controller Denes. From our Leader's own kitchens.
Sir.
And to read?
Well, something light. A book about foreign travels perhapsm hmm?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Head Chef is working.

Dialogue.Line: So you reckon you know about cooking?
Yes, I used to do lots at home.
All right, give me a menu.
What, now?
Yeah, now.
Soup. Fish. Meat and pudding. Er.
Dessert.
Yes.
Go on. What else?
Oh.
Yes, you're a bit too smart for me. All right then, let's have a recipe.
What, now?
Yeah, now.
Er, er. Oh, yes! Yes! We used to have a lovely pudding at home, with lots of almonds, eggs, lemon peel, candied peel, oranges, cream and, oh it was lovely!
You wouldn't know how to make it?
Oh it's quite simple, really. You sort of whoosh it up all together.
Well, that sounds easy. What's this whoosh-up called, then?
Kaiser pudding.
Oh that's great, just great. Yes, I've got a job for you, all right. Peel those spuds, yeah, now.
Is that the best you can do for her? The girl must learn.
Back at school, are we? Well, I suppose there are worse things. The place could be overrun with rats gnawing holes in the gas pipes so the ovens catch fire and burn the building down.
It isn't that bad, Griff.
Look, I'm only trying to help with the. See? There, you see? This chicken's browning too soon already. It'll be as tough as rubber.
Oh, Griff.
Now the soup's boiling. Did I put any salt in it? Dinner tonight's going to be national disaster. My mother was right.
What?
She wanted me to be a dustman. Here, look, do you want to do something useful?
Oh yes, please.

Well sit down and write out the menus. First course interrupted by bomb explosion. Second course affected by earthquakes. Third course ruined by interference in the kitchen. I'm going out for a walk. It'll probably rain.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Griffin leaves.

Dialogue.Line: He doesn't like me.
It isn't you. He's the same with everyone.
Even Salamander?
Listen. You must go away from here. Don't get caught up in Salamander's world.
Why? What do you mean? It sounds as if you don't like him.
Like him? I

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie enters.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, hello there.
Finish writing those menus.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Fariah leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Did you hear that?
Aye. Work on her. I have a feeling she can tell us something about Salamander.
All right. As soon as I can. What have you been doing?
I managed to slip out and tell Astrid everything that's happened.
Oh, you might have told me, Jamie.
There wasn't time. She's trying to get Denes away.
Oh, and take him to the Doctor? He'd believe Denes.
Aye, he would.
But how can she get in? Salamander's got guards everywhere.
She's got friends here. They're going to arrange passes and the right sort of uniform.
What sort of uniform?
Don't know. Messenger delivery or something. Shh!
Controller Denes has been arrested. I can't make up my mind whether Fedorin is to be regarded as the new Controller or not. GUARD 2: The burden of office is heavy, my friend. I remember when I was
All right, they're gone.
Astrid and Giles Kent were quite right, Salamander is an evil man. I can somehow sense it from all the people here.
Aye, he's bad all right. He's had Denes arrested, and he's got this man Fedorin eating out of his hand.
Why should he do that?
Remove the honest man and put a weaker man in his place, but somehow have a hold on him. That way Salamander can take over the territory.
Oh, I see. And when everything's in a turmoil because of the earthquakes.
Aye, and that's lucky to say the least.
But you don't really believe that Salamander could cause earthquakes, do you?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Outside the Kenowa Research Station, they are watching the eruptions and lava flows on television.

Dialogue.Line: I'm certain Salamander's causing the earthquakes, Doctor, and I'm sure your friends Jamie and Victoria will tell you just how bad he really is.
But why make earthquakes?

Years ago, Doctor, when one country wanted to invade another it set about attacking the confidence of that country, throwing it into confusion, making it weak. Then it was right for takeover. Now, isn't that exactly what's happening here, only in a different way?

What you're saying is that Salamander's found a way of harnessing the natural forces of the earth. It's a little difficult to accept. I'm not saying it's impossible, mind you. You say it's coming from the Research Station. Salamander's Research Station, eh?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor looks at it through a pair of binoculars.

Dialogue.Line: That's what I believe, in spite of. Shush! Wait a minute.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Kent looks outside.

Dialogue.Line: In spite of a number of reasons. He invented the sunstore, a brilliant advance. He found a way of directing conserved energy to areas starved of sun.
What made you suspicious?
All the money he was spending at the Research Station. The materials involved, the food stores. It didn't make sense. I had all the papers, all the requisition orders.
But that's valuable evidence!

All destroyed, and new ones appeared, and I was made out to be the criminal. All by suggestion, of course. I was discredited. And every accusation I made against Salamander was put down as an attempt to throw suspicion off myself.
A sort of Jekyll and Hyde character, perhaps, our Mister Salamander. It'll be interesting to see what report Jamie brings back.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Vehicles with sirens are heard outside.

Dialogue.Line: Security. Quick! Here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Kent lifts the lid of a box seat. The Doctor gets in.

Dialogue.Line: I hope there's plenty of air in here.
Yes, yes, yes.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Kent goes to the sink just as Benik enters.

Dialogue.Line: So. It's you. I might have known.
Do you have any authority?
You're on Research Station territory.
Not quite. Have a look at the boundary lines.
That's very clever. Well, what are you doing here?
I don't have to answer your questions.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Benik picks up the binoculars.

Dialogue.Line: Bird-watching, no doubt?
Perhaps.
Yes, there's a perfect view of the Research Station from here.
Really?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Benik takes a photograph of Denes off the wall.

Dialogue.Line: Well, well, well. A memento of the old days.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Benik smashes the photograph.

Dialogue.Line: You have no right to
Guard!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A guard enters, weapon ready.

Dialogue.Line: It was just an accident. Now then, you won't be staying in this vicinity, will you.
You can't make me leave here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Benik nods to the guard, who goes to the sink and smashes the crockery.

Dialogue.Line: Hey now, watch that!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Kent is pushed back, and the guard wreaks havoc on the cupboard contents with his rifle butt.

Dialogue.Line: All right. That's enough.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The guard leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Well, there's not much point in your staying here now, is there. Oh, I wouldn't complain to anyone about this if I were you, Kent. After all, nobody would believe you, would they?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Benik leaves. Kent helps the Doctor out of the box seat.

Dialogue.Line: Come on. Now do you believe the sort of people we're up against?
Unpleasant, yes, destructive, but not necessarily evil.
Why won't you believe me?
It is too important. I must be sure. Oh dear. What pretty crockery this is. Sad really, isn't it? People spend all their time making nice things, and other people come along and break them.
That's what I'm trying to tell you about Salamander. He's trying to destroy the world!
Facts, Kent. I must have facts. That's what I hope Jamie's going to bring back.
Halt! Why are you running?
I have an urgent message for Leader Salamander.
Your pass? You have not been here before.
No.
I thought so. Next time do not run. It is dangerous to run here.
I'll remember.
Wait! You like wine? My name is Janos. We drink wine together tonight?
I have to go and deliver my message.
Yes, but later you will come back?
Oh yes. Yes, I'll come back.
Just a moment!
I have an urgent message for Leader Salamander.
Yes, I heard you. Where is it?
It's private and personal.
I don't want to read it. Keep still.
I have to deliver this to Salamander personally.
You do have a message?
Of course.
Then show me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Astrid hands over some folded paper. The Captain hands it back.

Dialogue.Line: Very well. I know you from somewhere.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Denes drops his book. Janos picks it up.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, I think I must have dropped off. Thank you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Astrid has gone.
Jamie is eating at the kitchen table and Victoria is laying a trolley with cutlery for a meal when Astrid enters.

Dialogue.Line: Sit down. Go on with what you're doing. We've got to rescue Denes. Get him away from the building.
There are guards everywhere.
Yes, I know, but we must try.
It's a pity we can't get him to the Doctor.
That's exactly where I intend to take him.
Well, what's your plan then?
Look, I want you to, well, cause a diversion.
What do you want me to do?
Well, anything. But do it at eleven o'clock precisely.
Eleven o'clock, right.
I see, the second corridor on the right, thank you so much.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Astrid leaves because Griffin has entered.

Dialogue.Line: Er, yes.
Now we're a travel agency. I haven't met you before. What's wrong? It's bound to be something serious.
This is a friend of mine, Griff.
He's not a cook like you, I hope?
No.

Oh, well that's all right then. Well, I suppose this is as good a place as any for meeting friends. Come one, come all, I say! How's the food? Terrible. Terrible. I'll get the sack tonight, I swear I will. Maybe they'll shoot me, and I won't have to worry any more. No, they wouldn't do that, the firing squad'd miss me.
How are you getting on with the food for Mister Denes?
Well it's ready, such as it is. Now we don't want too much of a crowd in here.
Well, I'll be on my way, then.
No, no. You stay. I'll go. I'm only the chef here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Griffin leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Now, what can we give Mister Denes?
Er, do you like working for Salamander, Fariah?
It must be wonderful travelling all over the world with him.
I don't enjoy travelling. (She tastes the soup.) Oh, this is good. That Griff's a genius.
Well, why travel then?
Sometimes we do what we have to do, not what we want to do.
You don't have to work for Salamander.
Don't I? Don't I? What do you know about it?
I'm sorry, I was just
To you, Salamander is a god, isn't he? The saviour of the world. That's why you work for him. You saved his life, didn't you?
I
Don't you protect his life every day?
Yes! As I say, sometimes we do what we have to do, not what we want to do.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Night time. Salamander is writing.

Dialogue.Line: Nevertheless, whatever he's done or not done, he should be treated according to rank.

He will be moved soon. You can't expect much sympathy for him, you know, Bruce. Word gets around. I warned him about the earthquakes. He could have cautioned the people. Some of them might have been saved.
Maybe.
No maybe about it.
Who's going to control this zone now? Fedorin?
Fedorin. Oh, what a good idea.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Victoria is pushing a trolley.

Dialogue.Line: Be nice to Mister Denes.
I will.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Victoria pushes the trolley along the flagstone corridor.

Dialogue.Line: Give him a smile. It might make him forget the taste of the soup.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Griffin goes back into the kitchen. Fedorin is standing in front of the trolley.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, is this for Mister Denes?
Yes, yes, I'm taking it to him.
May I look?
Yes.
Mmm. Delicious.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Fedorin lifts the lids and palms the salt cellar

Dialogue.Line: Ah, very good. Where's the salt?
What?
You forgot something.
Oh, no. Well, I
Well, you run and get it.
Yes, yes.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Victoria runs back to the kitchen. Fedorin opens the box Salamander gave him. It contains crystals.

Dialogue.Line: The same girl I saw in the park. I suddenly remembered.
You say she was talking to the boy and girl?
She was on the same bench.
Coincidence?
She wasn't in messengers' uniform then. She is now.
Yes, she certainly hasn't delivered any messages to me.
Shall I alert the building?
No. No, I want to know where she comes from. Let her escape but have her followed. Frighten her away.
I understand. And the other two?
Oh, I'll deal with them.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Victoria arrives with the trolley.

Dialogue.Line: Ah, good.
Sorry I've been so long.
Oh, good. I'm looking forward to this. Thank you.
Just a moment. Has the trolley been checked?
I was just going to, sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Captain takes the knives from Denes.

Dialogue.Line: Don't any of you know anything?
Do you imagine I'm going to try and cut my way out of here? How do I eat without the knife?
It's none of my concern.
Try the spoon, Mister Denes.
And how do you cut a steak with a spoon?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Captain cuts the tiny piece of meat for him.

Dialogue.Line: It's a long time since I had my food cut up for me.
Watch him carefully.
Sir.
Thank you for your courtesy.
Fariah, come with me. I want a word with you and Griffin about breaking regulations.
Yes, sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Captain and Fariah leave.

Dialogue.Line: What's the time?
Six minutes to eleven.
May I stay with you? I'm Victoria.
Yes, of course. I'd be glad of your company. If you'll forgive me, I'm really rather hungry.
There must be some other way. I couldn't do it, Salamander, I couldn't do it. I stood there with this man's life in my hands and. This powder, I couldn't use it.
I give you the chance to become something. Somebody. You failed to take it, huh.
There must be some other way.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Salamander takes back the box of poison.

Dialogue.Line: (laughs) Of course, my friend. Don't worry.
What?
Don't worry. You try, you fail. So what, huh? The moon doesn't fall out of the sky. Come, sit down, have a drink, huh? Cheer up. We find another way.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Salamander puts some of the poison into a wine glass.

Dialogue.Line: I really did try.
Of course you did. Don't worry. Forget it, huh? I have an alternative.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Salamander hands the dosed glass to Fedorin.

Dialogue.Line: Your health. I hope you'll appreciate this wine. It's made for me especially in Alaska.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Fedorin drinks, clutches at his throat, and dies.

Dialogue.Line: One chance, my friend. I said one chance.
Some trouble in the kitchens, Leader. The new man says he's seen someone in the kitchen gardens.
Very well. Oh, see to that, will you? Suicide, of course. Such a pity.
I can't see anything.
Over there by the trees. Hey, he's armed, too. Get down. Look, I'm going out there, you stay down here. When the rest of the guards come, send them out after me.
Yes, all right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie goes out into the garden.

Dialogue.Line: This is just about the end of a perfect day.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A shot rings out.

Dialogue.Line: Here, I know the food's bad, but you don't have to go that far!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: More shots, and Griffin hides under the kitchen table.

Dialogue.Line: All right, have it your own way. Why did I ever leave Woolloomooloo?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: An armed guard runs past Janos.

Dialogue.Line: Astrid's going to try and get you away.
An attempt has been made to rescue this man. Get him out to the car.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Janos turns his back and Astrid knocks him out.

Dialogue.Line: I'm sorry, Janos.
Stop!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Denes is shot in the back.

Dialogue.Line: After them!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Victoria pushes the trolley into the guards, who fall over it.

Dialogue.Line: Get that girl!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Still outside the Research Station.

Dialogue.Line: Patience, Mister Kent, patience.
Astrid should have been in contact by now.
Oh, perhaps her plan to infiltrate into Salamander's organisation has failed.
Ah no, otherwise Benik's little visit here wouldn't have been so moderate. He wouldn't have stopped at breaking up the crockery.
Can't you contact her?
If I knew where she was. Oh no, I know she's in the Central European zone, but that's a big place. No, we'll just have to sweat it out and wait.
Well, your friend Benik did indicate we weren't entirely welcome here, you know.
Yes, it's not safe, and taking you from place to place isn't easy. And I mean, you're not exactly inconspicuous, are you?
Oh, thank you. Well, I suggest we give her another hour, and then if she doesn't contact us by then, we'll move out and find out what has happened.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Meanwhile, Astrid has returned to Kent's office. She turns on the videolink.

Dialogue.Line: Astrid, you're back. Switch to scramble.
Scramble? Are we being monitored? KENT [on monitor] It's possible. ASTRID [on monitor]: Right. Switching now.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The pictures and sounds scramble, so Benik turns on the security channel.

Dialogue.Line: Has Leader Salamander's ship arrived at the terminal? GUARD [on monitor]: I think it's due now, sir.

Good. Contact the guard. And I want the girl Astrid Ferrier traced. She's Giles Kent's assistant. I'll have an identiprint sent down immediately. She's somewhere in this zone. GUARD [on monitor]: Yes, sir.
Tell the Captain to inform me the moment he's found her, and to hurry. GUARD [on monitor]: Sir.
Denes dead?
Yes, shot in the back. KENT [on monitor] : Well, it looks as if our friend Salamander's had a real field day, doesn't it?
I'm afraid I haven't done very well. KENT [on monitor]: Don't worry. It's not your fault. Look, stay put and we'll join you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Transmission ends. There is a knock at the door. Astrid hides behind it as it opens, then pulls it wide to pull the visitor in.

Dialogue.Line: You! What are you doing here?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Astrid grabs Fariah from behind, arm around her throat.

Dialogue.Line: No, don't be foolish. What are you doing here?
I can't talk. You're choking me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Astrid releases Fariah, but keeps her covered with a gun.

Dialogue.Line: One move. Just one move.
You think Salamander sent me here.
Well, didn't he?
No, it was my own idea. I came here to see Giles Kent.
Why?
I have some information for him.
Why should you want to help him?
Because I hate Salamander probably even more than you do. I can help you to destroy him. I want to be there to see his face when he dies.
Come on, come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The monitor lights up.

Dialogue.Line: About time too. Is the Captain there? GUARD [on monitor]: Yes, sir. CAPTAIN [on monitor]: Here, sir. The girl Astrid Ferrier. She was in the Central European zone.
Was she? Well she's here now. Have you found her? CAPTAIN [on monitor]: Well, I think so. One of my men saw someone answering her description going into Giles Kent's office earlier.
Was she alone? CAPTAIN [on monitor]: Yes, sir. But shortly after someone else followed her in.
Well who, man, who? CAPTAIN [on monitor]: Leader Salamander's food-taster sir, Fariah.
Fariah? Right, I want the place surrounded, and I'll join you there. Get a move on! CAPTAIN [on monitor]: Yes sir.
Fariah.
But what are they going to do to Jamie and Victoria?
I don't know.
Hold them in the Central European zone until Salamander has time to deal with them.
No, you're wrong. Salamander doesn't care for loose ends. He brought them back with him.
What, to his headquarters, the Research Centre?
Yes. He's going to try to get information from them.
How far will he go to get it?
Very far.
Oh, that's very comforting.
I tell you, I know Salamander.
Yes, I'm not quite clear about your part in all this. You work for Salamander, suddenly you fall over yourself to betray him.
I came here for that purpose, yes.
Why?
Because I have every reason to hate Salamander. He blackmailed me into being his personal servant. I even had to smile when he told me to.
What sort of blackmail? What had you done?
Does it really matter?
Oh, no, no, no, of course not, my dear. Well, nobody's perfect, Kent. But I still can't help wondering why
Why I haven't tried to expose Salamander?
Well, you were in a unique position to do so.
Because without any proof I'd be wasting my time.
Proof! Proof! Proof! It always comes back to the same thing. No one has any evidence against Salamander!
We have some.
Not enough! It's not enough! Salamander covers up too well.
I have what you want.
But I thought that you said
No. Not about me. Fedorin.
Fedorin? A public embezzler who commits suicide?
Salamander engineered nearly every one of those swindles, and I can prove it.
How?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Fariah produces the dossier.

Dialogue.Line: Fedorin's file.
But that's wonderful. Let me see. I'll give it to you back. Thank you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor inspects the documents.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, yes. Yes.
Report your position, A three.
Keep well back, sir.
Is the building surrounded?
A three's in position, Captain.
Just closing up the gaps.
Well, you haven't brought me here on a fool's errand, I hope?
Still inside, sir.
Where's Kent's office?
Up on the second floor.
Hmm, right. We'll move in.
Just a moment, sir. What about the roof?
No reply yet, Captain. Position A five, position.
Come on, come on.
But I'm afraid this still isn't evidence. It's not real evidence.
You mean even this doesn't convince you about Salamander?
Oh, I'm not saying that.
Well then, you'll do it? You'll impersonate him?
And of course when they see you with me they're bound to think you're Salamander.
But I still don't know if I can carry it off.
It's the only way to get your friends released.
Yes.
Of course, there are
Oh, I see. Yes, of course, there are conditions, aren't there? You help me, I defeat Salamander.
Now look, you're giving me the biggest opportunity I'll ever have of ridding the world of this monster. Either I can convince you one way or I'll have to do it another.
What you really want me to do is to kill him, isn't it?
What else do you do when someone is evil?
Private justice, eh? Oh no, no. I'll expose him, ruin him, have him arrested, but I won't be his executioner. No one has that right.
Sometimes it's necessary.
No!
Yes, Doctor, yes! When the inducement is strong enough, and in your case, yes, you still want your friends out of danger?
You can't bargain with people's lives like that!
I can. Either you get rid of Salamander, or we won't lift a finger to help your friends.
Mister Kent, look.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Kent goes to the window.

Dialogue.Line: I'd make up my mind quickly if I were you.
Why?
Have a look out of the window.
Well, what is it?
A five reporting in, Captain. Every man's in position now.
Right, we'll move in.
Tell all men to shoot on sight.
I can't accept responsibility like that, sir.
You won't have any responsibility unless you do as I say. These people are terrorists. Give the order!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Captain nods reluctantly.

Dialogue.Line: All A positions, shoot on sight.
Forward.
No doubt of it. They're security men.
And they're closing in.
Well, isn't there another way out of here?
The usual ways will be blocked.
The fire escape.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Kent goes to another window.

Dialogue.Line: Up there, look!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The guards are coming down from the roof.

Dialogue.Line: More down there, too.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: At the bottom of the emergency exit, a woman pushes a pram past three guards.

Dialogue.Line: What do we do now?
Over here, quick!
What's that?
Through here. The ventilator shaft.
Giles, we can't.
Yes, of course.
Wait. The file.
Come on, quickly.
But where does it go?
It doesn't matter. Come on.
It's locked.
Kent! Why don't you just let us in. It'll save so much unpleasantness.
Now look. Just relax and you won't feel a thing.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Fariah slides down the shaft.

Dialogue.Line: Now you, Doctor, next.
Kent! Open the door.
Oh no, what about you?
Oh no, you're too important. You go, and Giles. I'll follow.
All right.
Very well.
You leave me no alternative. Break it down.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Kent and the Doctor climb into the shaft. Astrid shoots at the door.

Dialogue.Line: Get back!
Get away from that door!
Can you hear me in there? Why don't you come out?
I can hear you.
How long do you think you can hold out against us?
Standing by?
A five, progress.
Well?
He's outside the window now, sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: In the office, paper rustles in a slight breeze. Astrid turns as a guard comes in through the window. They struggle for the gun and it goes off, pointing at the ceiling. Astrid knocks the guard out.

Dialogue.Line: He's through, Sergeant. Smash that lock.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The guards break in.

Dialogue.Line: Well? Well?
Empty.
The air ducts. They've disappeared through the air conditioning plant. Is there a manhole exit from the plant to the street?
I don't know, sir.
Well, find out! On the double!
Attention all A positions. Cover the street. Send to the air conditioning plant.
Tell your men to shoot to kill!
Shoot to kill. Repeat, shoot to kill.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Benik and the Captain leave. Astrid comes out from under the desk.
Fariah, with the dossier, has become separated from the others. She encounters a guard in an alleyway. He shoots her.

Dialogue.Line: What do you think you're doing?
We had orders to kill.
Do you always obey orders?
I'm sorry, Captain.
Oh, never mind. Go and search for the others.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The guard leaves.

Dialogue.Line: I'm sorry, but you should have stopped.
Did you get the others?
Not yet, sir.
Now listen to me. There was you, Astrid Ferrier, Giles Kent and another. Who was the other man?
You'll know soon, soon enough.
I want to know now.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Benik puts his gun to Fariah's head.

Dialogue.Line: Sir, you
Shut up! Well?
You can't threaten me now, Benik. I can only die once, and someone's beaten you to it.
Who was the other man?
Sir! She's dead.
Good.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Benik picks up the dossier.

Dialogue.Line: Fedorin's file. Thank you.
What you mean is you failed.
I always said something should be done about Kent.
You always say. You say things but you don't think.
You exceeded your authority, Benik. A woman's been killed.
Resisting arrest.
Maybe, but you can't just take the law into your own hands. Giles Kent hadn't broken any rules that I know of.
I was sure he'd show himself one day. He was simply building up his resistance group.

Resistance group. The man's a traitor! These people are rebels. Bruce, you must find this man who impersonated me. The dangers are obvious. He could walk in anywhere at any time pretending to be me and ruin everything.
You can leave that to me.
How so?
Benik, come with me and I'll go over the security arrangements with you now.
Do as you're told!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Bruce leaves. Benik produces Fedorin's dossier.

Dialogue.Line: I think you'll find this interesting.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Benik gives the dossier to Salamander.

Dialogue.Line: What? The girl Fariah had this? What can I say?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Benik leaves, smiling broadly. Salamander turns on the intercom.

Dialogue.Line: Yes, sir?
The records room is out of bounds. I am not to be disturbed. See that the security locks are engaged.
Very well, sir. For how long, sir?
For as long as I say so.
Yes, sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: An alarm sounds. Shutters slide down across the doors and a man-sized capsule slides out from a recess in a wall. Salamander enters it. The capsule slides back into the wall, turns to the vertical and the shutters close. Salamander presses a button and the capsule descends into the earth very quickly. Thunderbirds are go.

Dialogue.Line: Are you telling me that no one, no one at all can see Salamander?
No one, sir.
Can you communicate with him on closed circuit?
I'll try, sir. He's turned off the master switch. Sorry, sir.
Here are all the security details. What's the matter now?
It seems that Salamander has locked himself away and can't be got at.
So?
Well, suppose the place caught fire?
It won't.
Don't be foolish!
Look, I can only tell you that when Salamander works in records, as he does from time to time, no one is allowed in.
I could understand if it were a laboratory or a research room of some sort, but a records room? What sort of records have you got in there anyway?
What did you want to see him about?
Never mind. I just don't like mysteries. Salamander's far too important to lock himself away like this. Anything might happen. A world emergency. Suppose I had to order you to let me in there?
It wouldn't do any good. When the locks are switched over they can only be opened from the inside.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Salamander enters a small room from the capsule and puts his jacket into a desk drawer and locks it. He is now wearing a dirty boiler suit. He turns on a monitor screen. In another room, a group of men and women are walking around with clipboards, attending machines and wall panels.

Dialogue.Line: I have returned. Take radiation precautions. I will make a report about the surface.
He's back. He's managed to get back again.
Let's hope he's got some good news this time.
Do you think Salamander's found some more food, Swann?
I hope so, otherwise we're finished. Where's that stock list?
Here.
Thank you.
Are you going to ask him?
You bet I am. He'll take me, too.
Colin, I couldn't sleep a wink last night thinking about you making the trip. None of the others have come back.

Don't stop me now. I've got to see the surface, Mary, I've got to. I want to see the Sun again, walk on top of the Earth, not hide like a rat underground. I've got to do it, Mary. I've got to ask him.
Yes.
Welcome back, Salamander. Are you all right?
Don't don't come too near, my friend. I am not yet decontaminated. I am too weary. Too utterly weary.
You shouldn't have made this trip, Salamander. You're doing too much.
Someone has to bring back the food for you, my friend, huh? You know that the radiation is slowly killing me, don't you, Swann?
You're just doing too much.
I worry about you all the time. What're you going to do when I am no longer here?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Salamander walks into a decontamination booth. The Geiger counter chatters.

Dialogue.Line: The radiation gets a little more each time, huh? One day, that needle will stay at maximum radiation.
Don't say that.
Why, Mary, Colin. It's my big joke, huh? Just to frighten you a little. I've got good news for us.
We can return to the surface?
No, no, no, not yet, but I've found another store of food.
Thank goodness!
And it is undamaged. Colin, open the last store of wine, huh? Go on, you help him too, Mary.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Colin and Mary leave.

Dialogue.Line: You must take it slowly, for goodness sake.
I'm all right my friend, I'm just a little dizzy. It's terrible up there, you know. Swann, you've no idea. Right, I am ready.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The wine is being poured.

Dialogue.Line: Here we are, my friends.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They cheer him.

Dialogue.Line: Oh please, no. It is enough that I am back with you again and I have brought food for you. Plenty of food.
Here's to the man who contrived
Please, Swann. I remembered on my way back down here that we are near our anniversary again. In a few short weeks, we survivors will have been down in this shelter for exactly five years.
Five years.
Colin and Mary were just teenagers then. Look at them now. We fed ourselves. But what's more than that, we are fighting back! We are doing something!
Yes! Yes!
Will we return to the surface, Salamander?
Yes, of course we will. This is what I'm striving for. But up there, it's terrible still. The war goes on and on, and you never know when the air is clean or when it's poison.
When can we return?
We have to fight for a while longer, hmm? Creating natural disasters, monsoons, earthquakes, volcanic eruptions, always in the places where the enemies of truth and freedom gather together.
You tell us this all the time, Salamander. When are we going to escape from this nightmare prison, that's all I'm asking you?
Colin, please.
I want an answer!
You shall have an answer, my friend. You will return to the surface when you have a good chance of survival.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Salamander staggers.

Dialogue.Line: You are ill.
No, no, it's all right. But you must believe me. Colin, all of you. You cannot return to the surface until is safe to do so. Please my friend, we must, we must

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Swann and Salamander return to the control room.

Dialogue.Line: You shouldn't have asked him, Colin. He's doing his best.
I can't help it, Mary. Next time, I'm going to make him take me with him.
No. You know the others didn't come back.
I've got to.
Then take me with you. I'd rather die with you up on the surface than live down here without you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: At the control room door.

Dialogue.Line: No, Swann. We must check the power levels, huh?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Salamander closes the door. Swann returns.

Dialogue.Line: All right, everyone to their places, please. Salamander wants to check the power levels. Come along there, come on. Full blast, that's right. Check the meter levels. Full power on line one, Salamander.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Salamander has his feet up and is smoking a cigar.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, good, good.
No faults indicated.
Excellent.
Stay where you are. I've been looking forward to meeting you again. Over there. No, not you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Kent and Astrid move away from the Doctor.

Dialogue.Line: Sit down, all of you.
How did you find us?
Your last visitor was Salamander's deputy, Benik. When he left, he fixed this underneath your trailer.
A radio tracking device.
On whose authority?
Mine.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Bruce looks at the Doctor.

Dialogue.Line: It's amazing how alike you and Salamander are. Incredible. You fooled me the first time we met, but now, even Salamander himself would think he was looking in a mirror. Why? You want this man to impersonate Salamander, why? How much are they paying you?
I beg your pardon?
They want you to assassinate Salamander, don't they? Take his place?
But that's ridiculous! I couldn't possibly do that.
But you were preparing to impersonate him, weren't you?
Well, well, yes.
All right then, why?
Because Salamander holds my two friends prisoner. I was going to attempt to rescue them.
And at the same time get evidence that would expose Salamander as a traitor, blackmailer and murderer.
Quite an ambitious plan. How do you know such evidence exists?
It exists in Salamander's records.
Oh, yes, I know why you want Salamander out of the way. You hate him because he exposed your profitable sideline of misusing public money.
Oh, it was Salamander who was misusing the money.
And I was dismissed from my post and the evidence against Salamander concealed.
So you say. But you've no evidence at all against Salamander, have you?
I tell you the evidence is in Salamander's records.
And I'm expected to take that from you?
We do hold evidence that Salamander isn't quite so pure and white as he's painted.
No? What?
A file, containing certain information about a gentleman called Fedorin.
Salamander was going to use this evidence against Fedorin. Blackmail him into submission. After he'd got rid of Denes, that is.
And so gain control of another zone.
Where is this file?
Fariah has it. Salamander's food taster.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Oops. The Doctor covers his mouth.

Dialogue.Line: Fariah? But she's dead.
Dead? But how?
She was shot by one of Benik's guards escaping arrest.
Oh, that's terrible.
Escaping arrest? Benik had her killed because she had evidence against Salamander.
And Benik will return the file to Salamander. We must get to the Research Station.

You're not going anywhere or doing anything. As far as I'm concerned, this story you've told me could be a pack of lies to cover your attempt to assassinate Salamander. Now I'm not saying I'm altogether satisfied with Salamander or his organisation, but I'll investigate in my own way.
Meanwhile Salamander will have found a way to cover himself, and also a way of disposing of you. You're digging your own grave, Bruce.
That's my affair. And I do things my own way.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Astrid grabs the guard's gun.

Dialogue.Line: And I do things my way. Really, as Head of Security, you should have more reliable guards.
Leader Salamander?
Still inside, sir.
Let me know the moment the doors are opened.
Yes, sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Two stretchers are carried across the corridor, with Jamie and Victoria on them.

Dialogue.Line: So you've brought them? Good. Any trouble?
No, a light drug saw to that.
Let me know the moment they wake up.
Yes, sir.
I'm looking forward to questioning them. I have a feeling they're going to be stubborn. It''s so much more interesting when our prisoners are stubborn.
You're only making trouble for yourself. Killing me won't get you anywhere.
We have to get to the Research Station, and you're not going to stop us.

But you're completely surrounded. You don't really believe I came here with just one guard, do you? You'd be very silly to try and fight your way out. I'd give you about thirty seconds to live if you try.
All right, Bruce, we might have just thirty seconds but you'd have exactly half that time, if you were lucky!
Please, Mister Kent! You're forgetting one very important thing.
What?
Me. Without me you haven't got an earthly chance of getting in that control centre.
So?
I told you before. I will not have anything to do with violence.
And what about your two friends? Are you going to leave them to the tender mercies of Salamander?
No, I am not. May I?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor holds his hand out to Astrid.

Dialogue.Line: What?
Please? Just trust me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor takes the gun from Astrid.

Dialogue.Line: Now then, I think you agree that at this moment your life is in my hands.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor offers the gun to Bruce.

Dialogue.Line: What are you doing?
Hold it.
It's all right. Mister Bruce isn't going to shoot anyone, are you?
Why? Why'd you do that?
Because I think I know what sort of man you are. Honest and reasonable.
Go on.
I gave you back that gun because I trust you. Now I want you to trust me.
You must be a complete fool or very clever.
Well, I'm afraid you will have to make up your mind to that right away.
What do you hope to gain by this gesture?
Your confidence.
Do you believe Kent's accusations against Salamander?
I think there's reasonable doubt about Salamander's personal integrity, but there's only one way to get proof.
By getting into Salamander's Research Station.
Yes. And my two young friends may have some information.
And if there isn't any evidence?
Then you'll be perfectly free to arrest us and put us in prison, won't you?
All right, I'll do it on one condition.
And what's that?
That you and I go alone. Kent and the girl stay here as hostages.
Now wait a minute. I must go with him.
No, Kent, you stay here. I must be mad to trust you. I only hope your impersonation of Salamander fools Benik. If it doesn't, we're in dead trouble. Here, take this.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Bruce gives the gun to the guard.

Dialogue.Line: Keep those two in the caravan. Oh, and watch the girl. Come on.
Swann, I'm back in the control room.
I placed the new food cases on the conveyor. Detail some men to unload them. Then make a report on schedule seven.
Jones, Morris, Hunt. Now remember, if there's any contamination showing up at all on the register you must tell me immediately.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A hatch slides open revealing a conveyor belt with a cardboard box labelled Milk on it. The men remove it and another labelled Canned Beans comes into view.

Dialogue.Line: Swann. Have you ever thought what would happen to us if Salamander didn't come back from the surface one day?
No. He always comes back. And talk like that isn't healthy. I've told you about this before, Colin.
You can live in a dream world if you want to.
Morale is important down here.
Reality is important, too. Facing facts!
Colin.
Yes, all right. I know.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Colin moves away.

Dialogue.Line: I'm sorry, Swann.
He's the best man I've got.
I know.
If only he'd just accept the fact that everything will
He never will.
He must be more patient then. We'll get out of here one day.
Will we?
Of course we will. Salamander says so.
Yes.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Swan moves away. Colin returns to Mary.

Dialogue.Line: Blind idiot. Why does he think everybody else has to be an idiot too?
We daren't let people think, Colin. Swann's all right.
I don't think it's right. Just work, sleep, eat, if there's enough to go round. Like worms under the earth, sightless worms wriggling about without hope, without purpose.
It isn't like that.
Isn't it? All this? Every day I ask myself what are we doing down here.
You've never doubted him before.
I don't know. I don't say I doubt him, but just once, Mary, just once I want to see with my own eyes what's going on up there. Me. Not hear about it from anybody else.
Are you getting on with your work? Mustn't fall behind, you know. Come on, Colin. We all get depressed. I know how you feel.
I'm sorry.
That's all right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Swann goes to the food boxes.

Dialogue.Line: Ah, how we getting on here? Ah, all this? It's a good haul.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He picks up a very light box labelled Meat.

Dialogue.Line: Stand by to make your report, Swann.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Swann notices a piece of paper stuck to another box.

Dialogue.Line: Reaching full power here, Swann. (Swann goes to the door to the control room. It is locked. He uses the intercom.)
Salamander, I must see you.
Not now, we are too busy.
This is urgent.
Oh very well.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Swann enters with the piece of paper.

Dialogue.Line: Now what's the matter, huh?
What's this? What is this?
What?
Newspaper. It's a piece of newspaper.
So?
Well, go on, look at it. Read it. Last year's date. Look at the bit of headline there. There!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Holiday liner sinks, many feared lost. Dated Friday August 16, 2017.

Dialogue.Line: Control yourself, Swann. You'll go mad.
Holiday Liner Sinks! You say there's a global war, radiation everywhere. How can there be holiday liners? Tell me how! You've lied to us, haven't you? Haven't you!
In a way, Swann, yes. I had to.
Had to? What do you mean, had to?
Well, it's true that the war is over, but have you any idea what happens to people who've been involved in a nuclear war? Have you?
Of course I haven't. I've been down here.
Those who are lucky enough to escape the annihilation have their bodies eaten away by radiation poisoning. They're deformed in mind and body.
But this, this, this newspaper?
They have a kind of society, but it's evil, corrupt. You don't think I could expose you to that sort of thing? Think of Mary and the other women.
You could have told me at least.
I decided not to.
You should have told me.
I thought it was best.
And what about the natural disasters we've been organising? The volcanoes, earthquakes?
Swann, they are not fit to live.
You're murdering them, killing them off.
I want you and the others to inherit the Earth. Make a new world.
Yes, I know all about that, but not at the price of wholesale murder.
It's not murder! If you could see, you would understand. It's an act of mercy.
There must be some other way.
No!
I won't take your word any more. I want to see for myself.
You, you, you, you''d be horrified.
Maybe.
The radiation would kill you.
I'll chance that.
Very well. But promise me one thing. You won't tell the others.
Why shouldn't I?
Because I am right and you are wrong! You wouldn't want to, you wouldn't want to hurt them like that, huh?
And if you're lying, and I want to tell when I get back?
How can I stop you? You'd better tell them you're coming with me. Say er, say you've persuaded me. Swann, trust me. Don't go ahead with this, huh?
I have to.
This is Swann speaking. It's nearly a year since anyone went on the surface with Salamander.
Salamander's changed his mind. He's going to take me with him.
There are more stores to bring down too. Salamander can't do it all on his own. We'll both be back soon with good news, I hope.
Why not me? Why? I asked him. He turned me down.
Colin.
Why not me? Why not me? Salamander, take me with you! Take me with you!
They've gone. It's no good. Please, Colin.
Why didn't he take me? I've got to get out of here, Mary. I've got to get out.
Jamie? Jamie?
What? Oh.
Here, drink this. The headache soon goes.
Where are we?
I don't know.
Let's find out.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie goes to the door. Benik enters with a guard.

Dialogue.Line: Don't leave us so soon. We're going to have a little talk.
Where are we?
You're in the Australasian zone. I had you brought here especially.
Why?
So that Salamander could ask you some questions.
For all the answers he's going to get, he might as well have left us there.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie sits down.

Dialogue.Line: Stand up when you talk to me!
You'll get nowhere by shouting.
On the contrary. I'm going to get everything I want from you two.
We'll not tell you a thing.
(laughs) That's good. I like that.
What?
Spirit. Resistance. And you've got plenty of both, haven't you, boy? Well I wonder how long you'll last. Five minutes? No, a little longer, maybe. Ten, perhaps?
What do you mean?
Come now, you don't think I'm just going to sit here and ask questions, do you?
You must have been a nasty little boy.
Oh, I was. But I had a very enjoyable childhood.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie punches the guard, but Benik gets Victoria with his gun at her head.

Dialogue.Line: Yes, I thought so. Spirit, plenty of spirit.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Benik releases Victoria.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, we're going to enjoy ourselves, aren't we? Now then.
I thought you were going to take us to see Salamander.
Yes, I will. But he'll expect me to do my little best first.
You lay a finger on her and I'll kill you.
Will you? How? No. I think the time's come for you to answer my questions, don't you? Come here, girl! If you don't, I shall have to shoot one of you. Oh, not a mortal wound. In the leg, perhaps?
You'd better go. Don't worry.
There, that's better. Oh, such pretty hair, don't you think.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Benik pulls Victoria's head back.

Dialogue.Line: All right, leave her alone. What do want to know?
Quite a lot. And you're going to tell me everything, aren't you.
All right. Yes.
Who's behind you? Is it Giles Kent?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The door opens.

Dialogue.Line: Ah, so they're here, are they?
Salamander, I thought you were in Records?
Have they told you anything yet?
Not yet.
Very well. Bruce and I will take over. You may go. And er, take your little puppy dog with you, hmm?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Benik and his guard leave.

Dialogue.Line: Now.
We can't tell you anything.
Of course not. We know everything. We know about Giles Kent, we know about the girl called Astrid, and we know about your friend, the Doctor.
I don't believe you.
A childish plan to impersonate me. That's the truth, isn't it?
Ah, but he didn't agree to it.
You two were sent to the Central European zone to stir up trouble.
If you want to know he truth, Giles Kent told us a story and we weren't sure. Before the Doctor could do anything, we had to come here and find out what person you were like.
Yeah, and we found that out right enough.
You see, Bruce, they're just terrorists. Not very big fry, either. All this nonsense about proof against me.
If you're doing so much good for the world, why are you so afraid for your own life?
Aye, why do you have so many enemies?
Personal guards.
Your own food taster.
And why destroy the one man the people trusted, Alexander Denes?
Aye.
What do you mean, destroy?
One of your men shot him.
Trying to escape?
He shot him deliberately.
Aye. And that girl Fariah, well, she was close to Salamander. She'd speak against him. I know she would.
Fariah is dead.
Dead?
You've had her murdered too, have you?
Why you.
Oh, Victoria, don't hit me! You wouldn't hit your old friend the Doctor, would you? I wouldn't leave you in the tender mercy of Salamander.
Doctor?
You don't believe me. Oh.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor pretends to pull a descant recorder out of his inside pocket, then whistles 'Twinkle Twinkle Little Star while he mimes playing it. Jamie joins in.

Dialogue.Line: Only you made me leave it in the Tardis.
It is him! Doctor!
Oh, Doctor!
Tardis? Tardis? What's that?
Well, it's a little place that we three have in common. You must admit they thought I was Salamander to begin with.
Yes. I concede that. But there's still no proof.
No, but there's enough doubt in your mind to make you go on asking questions, isn't there? That's why we came here.
I told you to let me know when Salamander was out of Records.
But no one's come out, sir.
What did you say?
He hasn't come out, sir.
Wait. What happens up there?
Oh, it ends in a ruined building. This is where I bring the stores. You would be safer here.
Safer?
Yes, the radiation. I don't think it filters down here.
I still want to see the surface.
You will, you will.
I should have insisted on going with him. Bruce should have taken me.
You know he doesn't trust you.
He wouldn't trust his own grandmother.
Oh, never mind, Giles. We've come a long way. Months ago, well, a few weeks ago even, nobody would have even listened to you.
Ah, maybe.
There's no maybe about it.
Yeah, perhaps you're right. Bruce listens to us at last. He's even prepared to ask questions, that's fine, but I know Salamander. He'd talk his way out of a quicksand.
Well, what else can we do? The guard's still outside.
I must get into the Research Centre. I've got to make sure that Bruce understands the evidence. Understands it, Astrid. Don't you realise he mightn't know what he's looking for. I know.
But we can't attack the guard. It would only make matters worse.
Not if I was to give Bruce real evidence.
Giles, how long would it take you to get to the Research Station?
Well, just a few minutes. I've got a pass. It's just a matter of getting there.
All right, I think I can help you. I'll draw the guard off and leave you alone.
You think you can do it?
Yes, I think so.
But I thought you said we weren't going to attack the guard?
Oh, we're not going to attack the guard. But there is going to be an attack. A fatal one.
Where does this lead?
It goes on up and comes out in a field.
What about radiation?
Here, it's almost negligible.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They pass some packing cases.

Dialogue.Line: You mean you could have brought others here from below? I don't understand you. Don't you realise what a break it would be for them, just moving away from that underground tomb once in a while?
You seem to forget, Swann, I've brought people up here before. There's always an element of risk.
I still want to have a look at these people you say are living on the surface. Where does that lead?
Oh, that's a dead end. It's a place I sometimes rest. It's very hard work, you know, bringing all this
Yes, I know that. This way, then?
You sure you won't change your mind, huh?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Behind Swann's back, Salamander picks up a metal bar from on top a packing case.
Astrid uses a sauce bottle to break the window. The guard rushes in. Kent is lying on the divan with a red stain on his forehead.

Dialogue.Line: What's going on here?
He's been shot through the window.
All right, stand back. Looks as though he's finished. Better get a doctor anyway, just in case.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Astrid runs out.

Dialogue.Line: Hey! Come back!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The guard chases after her. Kent gets up, tastes the ketchup on his forehead, picks up his jacket and leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Down there.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He points at a hole in the ground.

Dialogue.Line: Down there?
What other explanation is there?
Now wait a moment. Are you seriously trying to tell me without a shred of evidence that Salamander is attacking the world with natural disasters?
Well, he must be.
Yes, that's what I believe.
But it's beyond belief. How could he possibly?
I'm sure we'll find proof in the Records Room.
Maybe, but that's where Salamander is.
Ah. Well, we shall have to wait until he comes out, won't we, hmm?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Benik has entered the room.
Sounds of dripping water.

Dialogue.Line: Water.
What?
Water.
Yes.
